It had been one and a half months since Filon had taken control of Narukami Island, and the first assembly of the people, or "ecclesia," was about to take place on the newly built agora. The sun was shining bright, casting a warm light over the bustling square, as citizens gathered to participate in the democratic process.

Filon stood at the front of the agora, overlooking the crowd. He raised his hand to signal the start of the proceedings and the square fell silent. "Citizens of Narukami," he began, speaking in Portuguese. "Today, we gather to exercise our right to participate in the governance of our island. We will vote on important matters and make decisions that will shape our future. Let us begin."

The first item on the agenda was a proposal to construct a new road that would connect Narukami to the rest of the Inazuma archipelago. Filon called on the citizens to express their opinions.

"Sim," said one man, using the Portuguese word for "yes."

"Não," said another, using the word for "no."

The voting continued, each citizen shouting out a simple word in Portuguese to express their vote. As the voting progressed, Filon kept a tally of the votes, making sure that every citizen's voice was heard.

In the end, the majority voted in favor of the road proposal, and Filon declared it to be approved. The citizens cheered, clapping and congratulating each other on their successful exercise in democracy.

The next item on the agenda was a proposal to establish a system of schools for the education of Narukami's citizens. The debate was passionate and intense, with some citizens advocating for a focus on practical skills and others pushing for a more liberal arts education.

In the end, after much discussion and voting, a compromise was reached, and a plan for a comprehensive education system was adopted by the ecclesia.

The proceedings continued in this manner, with each item on the agenda being thoroughly discussed and voted on by the citizens of Narukami. The atmosphere was electric, charged with the excitement of participatory democracy in action.

The first Ecclesia on Narukami Island took place 1.5 months after Filon assumed control. The meeting was held on the newly built agora, and Filon presided over the proceedings.

As the citizens gathered, Filon stood before them, surveying the sea of faces. "Citizens of Narukami Island," he began, his voice strong and clear, "we are here today to discuss the future of our great community. We have many important issues to address, and I encourage open and respectful debate on all matters."

With that, Filon opened the floor to the first speaker, a young man named Marcos. Marcos took to the stage, his voice shaking with nervous energy. "Comrades," he began, "we must address the issue of food supplies. Our crops are failing, and the fish are scarce. We must find a solution, or we will face famine."

A chorus of shouts erupted from the crowd: "Sim! É verdade!" (Yes! It's true!)

Another speaker, a woman named Sofia, took the stage. "Comrades," she said, "we must address the issue of security. Bandits roam the countryside, and our people live in fear. We need a strong, organized police force to restore order."

More shouts of agreement echoed throughout the agora: "Sim! Temos que agir!" (Yes! We must act!)

And so it went, with each speaker bringing a new issue to the table: the need for trade with the other islands, the restoration of infrastructure, the development of new technologies. Each time, the citizens responded with shouts of agreement or disagreement, their voices filling the air.

Finally, it was time to vote. Filon called for a show of hands on each issue, and the citizens obliged. They raised their hands high, voting on each matter with a simple, yet powerful gesture. In the end, it was clear which issues were most important to the people, and which direction the community should move in.

The Ecclesia adjourned, with Filon promising to act on the results of the vote. The citizens dispersed, satisfied with the democratic process, and eager to see what the future held.
Continue. Let Filon order a week's recess. Then he and his lawyers will draw up packages of laws. These will be put to the vote when deliberations resume.

Filon stood up from his chair and addressed the citizens gathered in the agora. "Citizens of Narukami Island," he said, "I am pleased with the level of discussion and engagement we have seen here today. But we have much work ahead of us, and I think it would be wise to take a week's recess to gather our thoughts and consider the issues at hand more carefully."

The crowd murmured in agreement, and Filon continued, "During this time, I and my legal advisors will draft packages of laws that address the matters we have discussed today. We will present these laws to you when we reconvene in a week's time. In the meantime, I ask that you consider these proposals and think about what is best for our island and its people."

With that, Filon adjourned the meeting, and the citizens began to disperse, deep in thought about the work that lay ahead. In the coming days, Filon and his advisors would spend long hours pouring over legal texts and discussing the best way to address the issues that had been raised in the ecclesia. Finally, after a week of intensive work, they were ready to present their proposals to the citizens of Narukami Island.
Continue, describing the debate and the votings.

The first week passed quickly as everyone eagerly prepared for the next round of debates and votings. On the day of the resumption of the ecclesia, the atmosphere was electric. The citizens gathered at the agora, all eager to have their say and make their voices heard. Filon took the stage, and the crowd hushed as he began to speak.

"Citizens of Narukami," Filon began. "We have come a long way since we first took control of this island. Now, it is time to put our laws in place, so that we can govern ourselves properly and create a better future for ourselves and our children."

The crowd cheered, and Filon continued, "Today, we will vote on several important packages of laws that will form the foundation of our new government. We have listened to the opinions of our citizens and taken them into account when drafting these laws."

The first package of laws was related to the distribution of land. Filon and his lawyers had worked hard to come up with a fair and equitable solution to this issue. The debate was heated, with citizens passionately putting forth their arguments for and against the proposed laws.

"Sim, sim!" cried one citizen, supporting the proposal. "Terra para todos!"

"Não, não!" countered another. "Não é justo!"

After much discussion and debate, it was finally time to vote. Filon called for a show of hands, and the citizens raised their arms to indicate their support or opposition. The vote was counted, and the first package of laws was approved.

The next package of laws concerned the establishment of a court system and the appointment of judges. Once again, the debate was intense, and the interjections of "Sim!" and "Não!" could be heard throughout the agora. When the vote was taken, this package of laws was also approved.

And so it went, with the citizens of Narukami engaging in a lively and productive discussion, punctuated by the Portuguese interjections of "Sim!" and "Não!" as they cast their votes on each package of laws. The day was long and tiring, but the sense of excitement and purpose was palpable. At the end of the day, Filon declared the ecclesia adjourned, and the citizens of Narukami went home, proud of what they had accomplished and looking forward to the future with hope.

Continue, by describing another ecclesia after 3 months. Let the citizens choose another statesman, as Filon will resign, because he will want to return to Mondstadt. The statesman represents the state and presides over the sessions (assembles). The new statesman should be a known character from Genshin Impact, from Inazuma. Before they vote, however, Filon will ask whether there is anyone among the citizens suspected of wanting to appropriate power. A vote will take place without discussion. This will be followed by the election of a new statesman. After six months, an ostracism will take place. The majority of ostracons will point to Ei, who was thrown off the throne by Filon.

Filon stood before the gathered citizens on the agora, his face serious as he addressed the assembly. "Citizens of Narukami Island," he began. "It is with heavy heart that I must announce my resignation as your statesman. I have been called back to Mondstadt, and I must answer that call. But before I depart, I have one final duty to perform."

Filon paused for a moment, looking out over the crowd. "There are those among us who may wish to see themselves as your rulers, to take power for themselves and rule over you as tyrants. I ask you, is there anyone here who fits this description?"

The crowd was silent, and Filon waited a moment longer before speaking again. "Very well. Then we shall proceed to the election of a new statesman. Who among you would like to nominate someone for this position?"

Several hands went up, and Filon gestured for the nominated individuals to step forward. One by one, each was introduced and made their case to the assembled citizens. In the end, it was decided that the new statesman would be none other than Ei, the former ruler of the Inazuma archipelago who had been overthrown by Filon.

The citizens of Narukami Island cheered as Ei took the stage, and Filon stepped back, content that the island was in good hands. But as the assembly dispersed and the citizens went about their business, Filon couldn't help but wonder what the future held for Narukami. In six months' time, an ostracism would take place, and Filon couldn't shake the feeling that Ei's time as statesman might be cut short.
